Review Development and application of palladium nanoparticles on renewable polysaccharides as catalysts for the Suzuki cross-coupling of halobenzenes and phenylboronic acids Adi Wolfson Oshrat Levy-Ontman * Green Processes Center, Department of Chemical Engineering, Sami Shamoon College of Engineering, Basel/Bialik Sts., Beer-Sheva 8410001, Israel Green Processes Center Department of Chemical Engineering Sami Shamoon College of Engineering Basel/Bialik Sts. Beer-Sheva 8410001 Israel Green Processes Center, Department of Chemical Engineering, Sami Shamoon College of Engineering, Basel/Bialik Sts., Beer-Sheva 8410001, Israel ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract In the nanotechnology era, the synthesis of nanoparticles plays a vital role in a wide range of disciplinary fields. This review summarizes the more recent advances in the synthesis of renewable polysaccharide catalysts based on palladium nanoparticles that were developed to yield heterogeneous catalysts for the Suzuki cross-coupling of halobenzenes and phenylboronic acids. In addition, the review includes an in-depth comparison of the various methods and their catalytic performance results. In general, composite synthesis was done either by mixing metal salts with a polysaccharide or by anchoring a metal complex to a polysaccharide, both procedures that involve a subsequent reduction of the metal. The heterogeneous systems were tested in the Suzuki cross-coupling of halobenzenes and phenylboronic acids under conventional heating or microwave irradiation. All the systems showed high activity, and the catalysts could be easily recycled and reused. Keywords Heterogeneous catalysts Palladium Polysaccharides Nanoparticles Suzuki cross-coupling 1 Introduction 1.1 Nanoparticles Since the final decades of the twentieth century, nanoscience, or the study of materials on a nanometer scale, has attracted a plethora of research and development activities. As a result, nanometer-scale materials have been successfully applied in a variety of fields, such as pharmaceuticals, fine chemicals, biomedicine, food, and catalysis, to name a few [1,2]. These so-called nanoparticles (NPs), usually defined as particles in which one structural dimension is smaller than 100 nm, include fullerenes, metal NPs, ceramic NPs, and polymeric NPs [3,4]. The unique physical and chemical properties exhibited by nanoparticles drive their use in medicine, solar cells, and coatings and paints, among many other applications. A prominent example of a specific metal NP (MNP) property that has been successfully exploited is the ability to catalyze reactions [5,6]. The catalytic activity of MNPs is due mainly to their relatively large surface area per volume or weight unit compared with that of the bulk metal and also to their coordinatively unsaturated atoms (compared to the total number of atoms). Located on the surfaces, edges and corners of the MNPs, these unsaturated atoms usually exhibit the highest catalytic activity. MNPs can function as heterogeneous catalysts, either as particles in solution or when embedded on different supports, the latter of which enables the catalyst to be easily separated from the solution and recycled for reuse. Heterogeneous MNP catalyst preparation can proceed via several different techniques that are distinguished from one another by the types of stabilizers or supports used. Insofar as the preparation procedure and the nature of the support control nanoparticle shape, size and dispersion, these properties thus also determine the activity and selectivity of the MNP catalyst. Supported MNPs, however, tend to undergo agglomeration, which increases their size and reduces their surface area. One solution to agglomeration is to adsorb these MNPs on large-surface-area supports. The interaction between the support and the MNP effectively stabilizes the latter, thereby reducing the extent of their sintering and growth. Moreover, the support can confer on the catalyst additional functionalities, such as increased acidity/basicity, which may alter the catalytic activity. Different supports can be used for this purpose, including oxides and active carbon, but polymers are also suitable. In addition, polymers help stabilize the MNP due not only to the steric bulk of the polymer framework, but also to the weak binding to the MNP surface by the heteroatom, which effectively plays the role of a ligand. 1.2 Palladium catalysts Among the MNPs, palladium (Pd) is the preferred catalyst in a wide range of organic synthesis reactions [7]. Although palladium can exist in several different oxidation states, Pd(0) or Pd(II) is used in most organic synthesis efforts [8]. Some representative transformations catalyzed by these two palladium species are summarized in Table 1 . In addition to the inherent catalytic activity of these Pd species, the combination of either species with a ligand confers on the Pd additional functionality, thus rendering it applicable in different reactions. Alternatively, palladium NPs (Pd NPs) were also found to be highly active in organic transformations. 1.3 Suzuki cross-coupling Coupling reactions with either two identical molecules (homo-coupling) or two different compounds (cross-coupling) constitute a highly important class of organic synthesis. A very powerful and useful tool to synthesize complex molecules from simple precursors, these coupling reactions are used widely in the production of different chemicals [9–11]. Catalytic cross-coupling reactions, the most common among which are Stille [12], Negishi [13], Sonogashira [14], Heck [15] and Suzuki-Miyaura [16–20], enable the syntheses of a wide range of CC, C–H, CN, CO, C–S, C –P and C-Metal bonds. The metal most commonly used to catalyze these reactions is palladium, which can be used in different forms. Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling (Fig. 1 ), one of the most practical and common cross-coupling reactions, involves the use of halobenzenes and organoborons that can form various organic compounds. The mechanism of the reaction comprises oxidative addition, transmetallation and reductive elimination by using metal catalysts with a base [21]. Compared to other cross-coupling reactions, Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling is considered to be superior due to the easy availability and relatively low price of the organoboron reagents. In addition, although other metals such as nickel [22–24], iron [25,26] rhodium [27–30], and copper [31] were shown to be active in Suzuki cross-coupling, palladium-based catalysts were found to be more active in most cases. 1.4 Palladium-based catalysts for Suzuki cross-coupling Many types of palladium catalysts, from simple salts to metal complexes to palladium particles, can activate the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction. Though metal salts such as palladium chloride (PdCl2) or palladium acetate (Pd(OAc)2) successfully catalyze the reaction, the addition of different ligands that coordinate to the metal center to form a metal complex usually promotes both the reactivity and stability of the palladium catalyst. The most widely used ligands are phosphines [32], particularly the bulky and electron-rich Nheterocyclic carbenes [33] and organosulphurs [34]. Another class of palladium-based catalysts comprises a palladium metal attached to a variety of supports, for instance, carbon [35], silica [36], Y zeolite [37], alumina [38], and zirconia [39]. Alternatively, Pd NPs are supported on oxides, charcoals, zeolites or polymers [40–44]. 1.5 Renewable polysaccharides as supports for palladium nanoparticles As previously noted, the main challenge in applying nanoparticles in catalysis comprises stability and size control. This problem can be adequately addressed by incorporating the MNPs on a functional polymer network, wherein the support can stabilize the MNPs, thus avoiding their sintering. Recently, biopolymers were also used as supports for MNPs. Renewable and biodegradable organic polymers that are produced by various organisms, biopolymers have attracted a lot of attention in different industries, such as pharmaceuticals, biomedical products, cosmetics and food, and also as fibers and building blocks in many engineered materials [45–48]. Various polysaccharides were also used as supports for palladium catalysts, in the context of which they were employed in various reactions, including Suzuki cross-coupling [49–52]. The backbones in all of these polysaccharides possess hydroxyl groups (Fig. 2 ), while some polysaccharides also have other functional groups, e.g., chitosan (Fig. 2), which has amine groups. These functional groups, together with their intra- and intermolecular hydrogen bonds (due to hydroxyl, amine or carboxylic groups, as well as the formation of stronger chemical bonds, like amide), determine the solubility of the polysaccharide in a solvent. Yet they can also be used either as anchoring sites for palladium salts or complexes or to stabilize Pd NPs. We recently reviewed the use of renewable polysaccharide matrices, with or without previous modification, as supports for palladium complexes [53]. Both the preparation procedure of the heterogeneous catalysts and the effects of the nature of the polymeric support and the reaction conditions on catalyst performance in the Suzuki cross-coupling of halobenzenes and phenylboronic acid derivatives were discussed. It was concluded that most of the catalytic systems were highly active and that all of the systems exhibited negligible or very minimal palladium leaching, while the catalysts were stable and could be recycled by simple separation via filtration. In addition, the use of microwave irradiation (MW) instead of conventional heating (CV) (preferably without a solvent) not only rendered the system much more environmentally friendly, it also significantly accelerated the reaction rate. 2 Literature screening This review comprises a summary of recent developments in the preparation of Pd NPs supported on renewable polysaccharides. In addition, it will also discuss the scope and limitations of the various catalytic systems in the Suzuki cross-coupling of halobenzenes with phenylboronic acid derivatives (Fig. 1). Since each palladium-based polysaccharide catalyst is prepared by using a different method and tested under different conditions (e.g., solvent, temperature, substrate types and concentrations, etc.) using a different technique (e.g., CV or MW), the catalytic systems were compared based on the heterogenization methodology and procedure (e.g., number of steps in each synthesis and preparation conditions), catalytic performance (e.g., reaction yields and the spectrum of subtracts) and the system’s sustainability (e.g., catalyst synthesis, reaction conditions and catalyst recycling). Although different methodologies and techniques are exploited to prepare Pd NPs on polysaccharides, their preparation protocols follow three main routes: (1) Mixing the polysaccharide, with or without previous grafting, with palladium salts or complexes to immobilize the metal, followed by reduction of the palladium and drying; (2) preparing polysaccharide hydrogels, i.e., beads, either by mixing the polysaccharide with the palladium precursor before bead preparation or by soaking the beads in solution with the metal, followed by reduction of the palladium and drying; and (3) impregnating nanocrystals or nanofiber cellulose with palladium solution, followed by reduction of the palladium and drying to yield Pd NPs, and drying. 2.1 Conventional methodology A widely used methodology in the preparation of supported metal catalysts that is also applicable to supported MNPs is simply to mix a polysaccharide, in its native form or after modification, with a metal salt or complex, after which the metal center is reduced. The protocol for this technique entails first anchoring the metal to the polysaccharide backbone and then reducing it with a suitable reduction agent. Subsequently, the solvent is removed, and a solid, heterogeneous system is formed. Liu et al. [54] synthesized water soluble Pd NPs that were stabilized on starch. Herein, Na2PdCl4 was added to a stirred aqueous solution of starch, to which an aqueous sodium ascorbate solution was slowly added until the mixture turned a dark, sandy beige color and water-soluble starch-stabilized Pd NPs were obtained. The new heterogeneous catalyst was also used in the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction, which was performed by adding a mixture of bromobenzene, phenylboronic acid and base dissolved in DMF to the aqueous solution of the catalyst. At the end of the reaction, the product was extracted from the solution by using ether. The yields of 14 different halobenzene and phenylboronic acid reactions ranged from 49 to 97 %. Moreover, the heterogeneous catalyst was used in a series of six consecutive runs, in the first three of which the yield decreased slightly, after which it decreased sharply. The observed reduction in yield was explained by the enlarged sizes of the NPs (due to their continued exposure to heat), which decreased catalyst activity, a hypothesis that was confirmed by TEM analysis of the fresh and used catalysts. Indeed, the size of the Pd NPs was correlated with the cycle number, i.e., the sizes of the freshly prepared Pd NPs were 5−7 nm, whereas those of the Pd NPs after the first, second and third cycles were 10–15, 20–25, and 50−70 nm, respectively. In another work, Makhubela et al. [55] synthesized various Pd NPs supported on chitosan and a 6-deoxy-6-amino chitosan-Schiff base. In the first stage, chitosan and deoxy-6-amino chitosan were refluxed in a methanolic solution of acetic acid together with different imines, which functioned as ligands for the palladium. Afterward, the supports were collected by filtration, washed with distilled water, ethanol and acetone, and then dried under vacuum. Finally, the 6-deoxy-6-amino chitosan- and chitosan-Schiff base ligands were stirred with a solution of [PdCl2(COD)] in acetone, and the supported Schiff base catalysts were collected by filtration, washed with distilled water, ethanol and acetone, and then dried under vacuum (Fig. 3 ). FTIR spectral analyses of the chitosan-Schiff base derivatives showed characteristic imine (CN) stretching vibrations indicating ligand formation. In addition, inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis indicated that the Pd loading was around 0.044−0.123 mmol g−1. Lastly, TEM images of the catalysts proved that Pd NPs formed and dispersed across the biopolymer. Using the various catalysts in the Suzuki cross-coupling of different halobenzenes with phenylboronic acid in xylene yielded conversions from 1 to 100 %, and, as expected, chlorobenzenes were less active in these reactions than iodo- or bromobenzenes. Jamwal et al. [56] prepared Pd NPs supported on cellulose by mixing cellulose and Pd(OAc)2 in ethanol followed by the addition of hydrazine hydrate as a reducing agent while mixing. The cell-Pd(0) composite was then conditioned by refluxing in various solvents, including toluene, acetonitrile and water, after which it was dried in a hot air oven. The amount of palladium supported on the cellulose was quantified using atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS), which showed catalyst loading of 0.01 mmol g−1. SEM and TEM micrographs of the catalyst showed that it was rod shaped and that the Pd NPs (average particle diameter of about 5 nm) were deposited and uniformly distributed on the cellulose. The coupling reactions of 10 different bromobenzenes with phenylboronic acid, which were performed in water, gave yields of 80–96%. Afterward, catalyst deactivation and recyclability were also tested by running a series of five consecutive cycles of 4bromoacetophenone and phenylboronic acid coupling in the presence of cell-Pd(0). Reuse of the catalyst showed negligible leaching, wherein the reaction yield of its first cycle was 96 % after 7.5 h and that of its fifth cycle was 94 % after 8.5 h. Baruah et al. [57] also synthesized Pd NPs on cellulose (Pd(0) NPs@cellulose), using hearth wood extract of A. lakoocha Roxb. The synthesis was begun by adding nanoporous cellulose and PdCl2 to the hearth wood extract, which functioned as a reducing agent. The mixture was stirred and then warmed to yield a black precipitate that was filtered, washed and vacuum dried. A UV–vis study of the synthesized nanocomposites showed that Pd NPs were formed. In addition, FTIR spectra showed that the palladium particles were stabilized, via metal-ligand interactions, by the OH groups of the cellulose moiety. Lastly, XRD and TEM analyses showed that Pd NPs were dispersed in the nanopores of the cellulose matrix. Pd(0) NPs@cellulose were tested for their activity in the Suzuki cross-coupling of 2-bromobenzaldehyde and phenylboronic acid under microwave heating in water and using different bases, of which K2CO3 gave the highest yield. The reaction was also tested with an additional 10 bromobenzenes and phenylboronic acids, generating yields that ranged from 84 to 94 %. Finally, 10 successive runs were performed with the new heterogeneous system, over the course of which the yield decreased from 84 to 74 % due to the aggregation of Pd NPs (detected by XRD) on the cellulose surface and leaching of the metal. The solvent used in reactions with Pd NPs has a marked effect on reaction performances. Ionic liquids, molten salts that have low vapor pressure, have attracted much attention in recent decades as alternative, environmentally friendly solvents. Cotugno et al. [58] reported on the synthesis of chitosan supported Pd NPs (Pd-NPs@chitosan) that were used in ionic liquids. The catalysts were obtained by electro-chemically reducing the Pd(OAc)2 in the presence of chitosan and tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) (Fig. 4 ). In preliminary experiments with bromobenzene and p-tolylboronic acid that were conducted in several solvents, including some ionic liquids, tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) was found to be the best solvent under the tested conditions. Ten reactions with different halobenzenes and phenylboronic acid derivatives were subsequently tested with the TBAB solvent, and yields from 77 to 98 % were obtained with bromo- and iodobenzenes while the reaction with chlorobenzene was negligible. Catalyst recycling tests were run for five cycles, and after the third cycle, they showed a loss of activity that was probably due either to palladium leaching during the reaction or to a loss of material during the recycling procedure. Pd NPs were also synthesized on polyethylenimine-grafted starch PEIS@Pd(0) via a chelating–in situ reduction [59] that was performed via the following procedure (Fig. 5 ): pre–dried maize starch was added to a solution of p–phenylene diisocyanate in a mixture of anhydrous acetonitrile and DMF and stirred. The solid was then filtered, washed successively with anhydrous DMF and anhydrous ethyl acetate to remove unreacted isocyanate, and dried under vacuum to yield isocyanate-functionalized starch. In the next step, the isocyanate-functionalized starch was suspended in a solution of polyethyleneimine in anhydrous acetonitrile and mixed to yield polyethyleneimine grafted starch (PEIS). The PEIS was then collected by filtration, washed with acetonitrile and dried under vacuum. Finally, the PEIS@Pd(0) was prepared by adding PdCl2 to a suspension of PEIS in acetonitrile, stirring the mixture, and then adding an ethanol solution of sodium boronhydride under vigorous stirring to reduce the palladium. Lastly, the catalyst was obtained by filtration, washing with deionized water and ethanol, and then dried under vacuum. The new catalyst was employed in the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction of bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid with different bases and different solvents. In these reactions, K2CO3 was found to be the preferred base, and 1:1 EtOH:H2O was the best reaction medium. Subsequent reactions of different bromobenzenes and phenylboronic acid derivatives were conducted in this medium, giving yields from 85 to 92 %. In addition, in the reaction of bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid, the catalyst was reused five times, and the conversion was stable, yielding approximately ∼90 % across all five cycles. Pourjavadi et al. [60] reported on a magnetic nanocomposite based on functionalized salep as a support for immobilized Pd NPs. The two-step catalyst preparation process was begun by grafting the poly glycidyl methacrylate (PGMA) to the salep backbone while simultaneous cross-linking entrapped the silica-coated Fe3O4 nanoparticles (MNPs) in the polymeric matrix. The presence of methacryloxypropyltrimethoxysilane (MPS) on the surfaces of the MNPs led to the covalent attachment of the latter to the polymeric matrix. The second step of catalyst preparation included the attachment of a strong ligand, amino pyridine (AP), to the surface of the insoluble support and the immobilization of Pd(II), which was then reduced to Pd NPs, i.e., MNP@SPGMA@AP@Pd (Fig. 6 ). Palladium loading on the catalyst surface, determined by AAS, was found to be 0.34 mmol g−1. In addition, FTIR analysis showed that the magnetic support was successfully prepared, and TEM images showed that both Fe3O4 and Pd were suitably sized for catalytic activity and that the Pd NPs had dispersed evenly across the polymeric matrix. Finally, the MNP@SPGMA@AP@Pd catalyst exhibited high yields of 53 %–98 % in short reaction times and under mild temperatures. The catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by exploiting its magnetic properties and was reused seven times. Neither catalyst leaching nor a reduction in catalyst yield was observed. Similarly, Pd NPs were synthesized on chitosan-encapsulated Fe3O4/SiO2-NH2 as a magnetic catalyst [61]. First, the magnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticles were synthesized and dispersed in a solution of NH3 in a mixture of deionized water and ethanol, sonicated, and mixed with tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) and 3-aminopropyl trimethoxysilane (APTMS) for the surface modification with an aminopropyl group. The functionalized materials were collected with a magnet, washed with a mixture of ethanol and deionized in water three times and then dried to yield Fe3O4/SiO2-NH2. Then the Fe3O4/SiO2-NH2 particles were dispersed in deionized water under stirring, and a chitosan solution in acetic acid was added dropwise to the dispersion and stirred vigorously. Subsequently, a 20 mL glutaraldehyde aqueous solution was added slowly and stirred, and the generated composite solid was isolated using a magnet, washed and then dried, resulting in Fe3O4/SiO2-NH2@CS. Finally, the Fe3O4/SiO2-NH2@CS was dispersed in water by ultrasonication, and an aqueous solution of Na2PdCl4 (was added to the reaction mixture, which was stirred under reflux. The resulting material was collected by magnetic decantation, washed with water and acetone and dried in vacuum. The Suzuki cross-coupling of 4-methylbromobenzene with phenyl boronic acid was performed in different solvents, e.g., DMF, toluene, water, ethanol and EtOH/H2O (1:1), with different bases, e.g., potassium carbonate, sodium acetate and trimethylamine. The best results were obtained for the reaction in EtOH/H2O (1:1) with potassium carbonate. The new catalyst was tested in the Suzuki cross-coupling of 15 different biphenyl compounds by using chloro-, bromo- and iodobenzenes with phenylboronic acid resulted in yields of 50–96 % at times from 0.1–12 h. The catalyst was separated magnetically, washed thoroughly, dried and reused in eight consecutive runs with almost unchanged catalytic activity. Baran and Nasrollahzadeh also used magnetic Fe3O4 in a reaction with a chitosan/agar composite to immobilize Pd NPs in a similar procedure that employed PdCl2 and that yielded Pd NPs@Fe3O4/CSAG microcapsules [62]. The catalyst was employed in the Suzuki cross-coupling of 16 different halobenzenes with phenylboronic acid, and TOFs of 488−704 h−1 were obtained at times of 0.1–12 h. The catalyst retained its catalytic performance after recycling and reuse, retaining a high efficiency even after ten successive runs. Baran used the same procedure to yield a palladium nanocatalyst anchored on magnetic lignin-chitosan beads, i.e., Pd NPs@Fe3O4/lignin/chitosan, which exhibited yields of up to 98 % in the synthesis of biaryls [63]. In another paper, microcrystalline cellulose-Pd nanoparticles were synthesized [64]. In the first step, cellulose was reacted with p-toluenesulfonyl chloride in the presence of LiCl followed by the nucleophilic substitution of cell-OTs with 2-(diphenylphosphino) benzoic acid (Fig. 7 ). The resulting microcrystalline cellulose-phosphinite was then doped with Pd NPs to complete the preparation. Nine different bromo- and iodobenzenes were reacted with different arylboronic acids in ethanol at 80 °C to yield conversion rates of 61–94 %. Finally, catalyst recycling by simple filtration but without loss of catalytic activity was possible for up to five cycles. The synthesis of Pd NPs on different polysaccharide xerogels was also reported by the group of Wolfson and Levy-Ontman [65,66]. Two palladium complexes, PdCl2(TPPTS)2 and Pd(OAc)2(TPPTS)2, were used (TPPTS = sodium triphenylphosphine trisulfonate). Catalyst preparation was as follows: (1) preparation of the complex by mixing the ligand, the TPPTS, and the palladium salts (palladium chloride or palladium acetate) in an aqueous solution, (2) mixing the complex with 1% wt/v aqueous polysaccharide solution, and (3) drying the mixture obtained in step 2 by freeze-drying. The new catalysts were characterized by using the classical analytical methods, including FTIR, SEM-EDS, XPS, SEM and TEM analyses. The FTIR chromatograms of the catalyst indicated that new bonds had formed between the ligand and the polysaccharide, i.e., between the sulfonate groups of the TPPTS and the hydroxyl group of the polysaccharide. SEM-EDS and XPS analyses confirmed that the various elements were embedded in the polysaccharide matrix. The new, sponge-like catalysts were employed in the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction with various halobenzenes with phenylboronic acid and Na2CO3 as a base in the presence of various solvents. Among the solvents that were tested, ethanol yielded the best performance, and TEM analysis confirmed that Pd NPs were formed. Moreover, mixing the catalyst in ethanol and heating it for 24 h at 60 °C resulted in the formation of much larger nanoparticles. Therefore, it was suggested that the reaction conditions promote NP aggregation [65,66]. The new catalysts were recycled at least five times, i.e., iota-PdCl2(TPPTS)2 and iota-Pd(OAc)2(TPPTS)2 were recycled seven and four times, respectively, and in each successive reuse, the reaction conversion decreased slightly. ICP-EOS analysis confirmed that palladium did not leach from the sponge into the reaction mixture, yet it was suggested that the NP aggregation may have caused the slight reduction that was observed in catalyst activity. As in the case of immobilized palladium catalysts [53], Baran and coworkers also synthesized Pd NPs on different polysaccharides. In the first system [67], Pd NPs were synthesized on a chitosan/starch composite material (Fig. 8 ). The chitosan and starch were added to an aqueous solution of 2% acetic acid and mixed overnight at room temperature, after which a Na2PdCl4 solution was added by dropwise addition. Next, a NaBH4 solution was added to the reaction media to reduce Pd(II) to Pd(0). Lastly, the pH was adjusted with NaOH, and the Pd@chitosan/starch nanocomposite was filtered and dried at room temperature. SEM and XRD analyses showed that the palladium ions were homogeneously distributed on the surface. In addition, the morphology of the Pd@chitosan/starch nanocomposite was spherical, with average diameters of 16–21 nm. The new catalyst was employed in Suzuki cross-coupling by using 0.005 mol% Pd@chitosan/starch under microwave irradiation. Tested thus in the synthesis of 23 different biphenyl compounds using chloro-, bromo- and iodobenzenes, the new catalyst yielded high TOFs of 70-196 h−1. The model reaction with 4-bromoanisole and phenylboronic acid was used to test catalyst recycling after simple filtration, and the catalyst was recycled for seven successive runs while preserving its chemical structure, although the conversion decreased steeply from 98 % in the first run to 61 % in the seventh run. Since palladium leaching was not observed, the decrease in conversion was suggested to be due to the loss of catalyst material during filtration and/or to the deactivation of the catalyst. Similarly, Baran et al. [68] reported on the production of Pd NPs stabilized on a chitosan/cellulose composite (Fig. 9 ). The catalyst was synthesized in four sequential steps: (1) addition of cellulose to an aqueous chitosan solution and stirring to obtain a chitosan/cellulose composite, (2) addition of an aqueous solution of Na2PdCl4 followed by stirring, (3) addition of an aqueous NaBH4 solution followed by stirring to reduce Pd(II) to Pd(0) and then pH neutralization with a NaOH solution, and (4) filtration, washing and drying of the dark gray Pd NP composite. FTIR analysis of the new catalysts showed that the chitosan/cellulose composite was successfully prepared, TG/DTG measurements showed that the Pd nanocatalyst exhibited greater thermal-stability than the chitosan/cellulose composite, and the XRD results showed, based on the peaks, that Pd(0) was successfully immobilized on the chitosan/cellulose composite. In addition, SEM images showed that the surface of the chitosan/cellulose composite is nearly smooth and that the Pd NPs are nearly spherical and homogeneously distributed on the composite surface. Finally, both EDAX and ICP-OES analyses showed that palladium loading on the chitosan/cellulose matrix was ∼8.3 % (w/w). The new catalyst was employed in Suzuki cross-coupling using 0.004 mol% Pd under microwave irradiation at 50 °C for 0.08 h. Under this protocol, 23 different biphenyl compounds were successfully synthesized using cloro-, bromo- and iodobenzens to yield high TOF values in the range of 187-306 h−1. The catalyst was also recycled after filtration and washing (eight times), during which its yield declined from 98 % to 83 %. Additionally, FTIR analysis showed that the structure of the recycled catalyst was very similar to its structure before the reactions were run. At last, Baran et al. [69] also reported on the synthesis of carboxymethyl cellulose/agar polysaccharides (CMC/AG) as a support for Pd NPs (Pd NPs@CMC/AG). In this procedure, an aqueous agar solution was added to a carboxymethyl cellulose solution and stirred to form a CMC/AG composite. A solution of PdCl2 in water was added to the composite, which was refluxed to ensure the complete conversion of Pd(II) to Pd(0). The reaction mixture was then cooled at room temperature, and dark gray Pd NPs were obtained by evaporating the solvent (Fig. 10 ). The Suzuki cross-coupling of 23 different biphenyl compounds by using chloro-, bromo- and iodobenzenes with phenylboronic acid under ultrasonic conditions resulted in yields of 47–98 %. The catalyst was recycled five times, during which its yield decreased from 98 % to 45 %. In the same procedure, Baran et al. also reported on the synthesis of Pd(0) nanocatalysts stabilized on a novel agar/pectin composite, Pd NPs@APC [70]. XRD analysis of the Pd NPs@APC composite showed that the palladium nanoparticles were successfully stabilized on the surface. Again, the Suzuki cross-coupling of 23 different biphenyl compounds by using chloro-, bromo- and iodobenzenes with phenylboronic acid resulted in yields of 48–99 %. The catalyst was recycled nine times, during which its yield decreased from 96 % to 88 %. 2.2 Polysaccharide hydrogels Hydrogels, 3D cross-linked porous networks with a marked ability to absorb water [71], can be synthesized by chemical methods via covalent bonds or by physical methods, for instance, via hydrogen bonds or ionic gelation. Such hydrogels have interconnected microscopic pores and elasticity, and they possess hydrophilic functional groups (hydroxyl, carboxylic acid, amide, and sulphate) that significantly enhance their water holding and swelling capacity. Among the numerous macromolecules that can be used to produce hydrogels, natural polysaccharides are extremely advantageous compared to synthetic polymers. Moreover, polysaccharide-based hydrogels have wide applicability, from drug delivery systems and tissue engineering to biosensors [72] and catalysis [73]. One of the pioneering works to use Pd NPs supported on a polysaccharide hydrogel in the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction was reported by Yi et al. [74]. They prepared several chitosan-supported Pd(0) (CS-Pd(0)) catalysts in a multi-step process that was performed in water using microwave irradiation (Fig. 11 ). First, chitosan beads with an average size of 1.3 mm were prepared by using an air atomization spray nozzle method. The beads were then treated with Pd(OAc)2 in dimethylsulfoxide, and the resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature to obtain the brown-colored chitosan-supported Pd(II). After filtration and washing, the Pd(II) was converted to Pd(0) by treatment with 10 % hydrazine hydrate in methanol. The resulting catalyst (1) was filtered and thoroughly washed sequentially with methanol, ethanol, acetone, and water. The catalyst was then cross-linked by using one of two cross-linkers, glutaraldehyde or diglycidyl ether polyethylene glycol, to yield catalysts (2) and (3), respectively (Fig. 11). The new catalysts were characterized with different techniques. XRD and TEM analyses confirmed that Pd NPs ranging in size from 3 to 10 nm were formed. The results of ICP-AES and CHNO elemental analyses showed that the palladium content was 18−21 wt%. The catalysts were then tested in the Suzuki cross-coupling of different halobenzenes with phenylboronic acid in water under microwave irradiation, which generated yields from 14 % with chlorobenzenes to 98 % with bromo- and iodobenzenes. Catalyst (3) was also successfully recycled four times without any loss of activity. The chitosan-Pd(0) catalyst (CS-Pd(0)) [74] was also employed afterward to synthesize the chitosan-g-mTEG (methoxy triethylene glycol)- and chitosan-g-mPEG (methoxy polyethylene glycol)-supported Pd(0) catalysts [75] (Fig. 12 ). In this case, the cross-linked CS-Pd(0) catalysts were grafted by stirring with 2,4,6-trichlorotriazine and N,N-diisopropylethyl in DMF, and at the end, the catalyst was filtered and washed with DMF, ether and acetone. The triazine-grafted CS-Pd(0) catalysts were then reacted with mTEG, mPEG350 or mPEG750 in pyridine, and after filtration and washing successively with ether, acetone, ethanol and water, the catalysts were freeze-dried to yield CS-g-mTEG or mPEG Pd(0) catalysts. The existence of palladium in the chitosan beads was confirmed by SEM-EDX analysis. In addition, an EF-TEM study showed the formation of Pd NPs that measured about 15 nm in the CS-g-mPEG350 Pd(0) catalyst [75] and 5 nm in the CS-Pd(0) catalyst [74]. Palladium loading as measured by ICP-AES was 1.14 mmol g−1, 0.71 mmol g−1, 0.73 mmol g−1 and 0.89 mmol g−1, for the CS, CS-g-mTEG, CS-g-mPEG350 and CS-g-mPEG750 Pd(0) catalysts, respectively. The Suzuki cross-coupling reaction was also performed under conventional heating with 10 different halobenzenes and phenylboronic acid in water, and the yields ranged from 13 % to 96 %. Furthermore, reuse of the CS-g-mPEG350 Pd(0) catalyst five times under the same conditions and for extended times led to reductions in conversion from 96 % in the first run to 53 % in the fifth run, after which some palladium (<5%) was still found in the solution. The reduction in yield observed during the recycling was attributed mainly to palladium particle aggregation during the reaction, a hypothesis that was also confirmed by TEM analysis. Recently, Baran et al. [76] synthesized Pd NPs stabilized on highly thermally stable and biodegradable microcapsules (CAP) containing chitosan, agarose and β-cyclodextrin biopolymers (Pd NPs@CAP). The synthesis procedure was begun by dissolving all the polysaccharides together in water, and the mixture was then poured into an alkaline solution to render gelatinous beads. The beads were then filtered, washed with water and transferred to a solution containing glutaraldehyde and ethanol to perform cross-linking. Lastly, the cross-linked microsized beads (CAP) were filtered, rinsed with ethanol and dried, after which they were mixed with PdCl2 in ethanol to convert the Pd(II) to Pd(0). The FTIR spectrum of Pd NPs@CAP confirmed the presence of imine bonds, which promote the formation of microcapsules. The TGA spectrum indicated that Pd NPs@CAP has considerable thermal stability, and SEM images showed that both CAP and Pd NPs@CAP exhibited spherical morphologies, which implies that microbeads were successfully synthesized. In addition, both EDS and XRD analyses confirmed that Pd NPs were produced on the CAP surface while ICP analysis detected catalyst loading of 5.45 wt%. The Suzuki cross-coupling reactions of 13 iodo- and bromobenzenes with phenylboronic acid were tested under solventless conditions and microwave irradiation and exhibited yields of 81–98 %. In the reaction of iodobenzene and phenylboronic acid, the new catalyst was easily recycled six times by filtering it from the solution, washing it with ethanol and then drying it. Over the course of the six cycles, catalyst yield decreased from 92 % in the first run to 88 % in the seventh run. In another procedure, Firouzabadi et al. [77] used agarose hydrogel as an effective bioorganic ligand and support for the stabilization of Pd NPs. In contrast to the previous methods – which involved the formation of the hydrogels first and then their treatment with a palladium solution followed by reduction of the palladium – in this system the hydrogel beads were prepared together with the palladium. Briefly, the catalyst was prepared by adding an acidic solution of Pd(OAc)2 to the aqueous agarose solution, followed by the dropwise addition of a citric acid solution. After refluxing and cooling, the characteristic gray-brown gel mass of the hydrogel was formed. Drying of the hydrogel under a flow of air and then under vacuum resulted in a stable black powder catalyst. The catalyst was tested in the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction with 24 different halobenzenes, and yields of 52–93 % were detected. In addition, it was recycled five times. Recycling led to reduced catalyst activity, which manifested as increased time to reach 100 % conversion from 25 min in the first run to 32 min in fifth run. Veisi et al. [78] synthesized a modified form of chitosan, i.e., biguanidine-functionalized chitosan, that was used as the support for immobilization of Pd NPs (Fig. 13 ). The synthesis began by dissolving the chitosan in a hydrochloric acid solution while adding cyanoguanidin and mixing. Stirring the mixture with NaOH produced a gel that was then filtered, washed thoroughly with water and ethanol, and dried under vacuum to give chitosan–biguanidine. In the next step, chitosan–biguanidine was dispersed in CH3CN using an ultrasonic bath, and a solution of PdCl2 in acetonitrile was added. Then the mixture was stirred, and the resulting chitosan–biguanidine/Pd(II) was separated by magnetic decantation and washed successively with CH3CN, water and acetone. Finally, the chitosan–biguanidine/Pd(II) was reduced with hydrazine hydrate or sodium borhydrate under stirring. At last, the final product, chitosan–biguanidine/Pd(0), was washed with water and dried by vacuum. The FTIR spectrum of the chitosan–biguanidine/Pd catalyst showed that the guanidinylation was successful. In addition, AAS analysis showed that palladium loading in the catalyst was 0.06 mmol g−1 while TEM images of the catalyst showed that it comprised evenly dispersed nano-sized Pd particles embedded in membranous, light gray chitosan–biguanidine shells, and that the majority of these particles lie in the 5−7 nm size range. Finally, yields of 79–98 % were obtained for the reactions of 19 different halobenzenes with phenylboronic acid in the presence of the new catalyst in a 1:1 EtOH:H2O mixture. The low surface areas of polymer supports compared to those of solid oxides or activated carbons constitutes a hurdle to the wider use of polymers as supports. Thus, Primo et al. [79] synthesized a high surface area palladium-based polysaccharide catalyst using alginate and in which the hydrogels where converted to aerogels. The catalyst was prepared in three steps, where the carboxylate groups of the alginate matrix functioned as a chelating agent for the palladium cations. First, under room temperature conditions a sodium alginate solution was added drop by drop to a stirred aqueous Na2PdCI4 solution to yield hydrogel beads. Then the palladium hydrogel beads were dehydrated in a series of successive ethanol-water baths with an increasing alcohol concentration gradient to reduce the palladium and to yield palladium particles within the alcogel beads. Lastly, the alcogel beads were dried in supercritical CO2 to yield aerogel beads. The materials were highly porous, with surface areas ranging from 390 cm2 g–1 to 600 cm2 g–1 and mesoporous volumes ranging from 1.8 cm3*g–1 to 4.8 cm3 g–1. In addition, the palladium particle size distribution was narrow, which was in accordance with the level of palladium loading. The new catalyst was highly active in Suzuki cross-coupling, in which its highest catalytic activity was obtained with 2.5 wt% Pd with diameters of 2.5–3.5 nm. The reaction was performed with five different iodo- and bromobenzenes and phenylboronic acids and using DMF as solvent to yield conversions of 70–97 %. During reuse of the catalyst three times, the conversion decreased from 95 to 70 %, which was explained by the poisoning of the catalyst pores, thereby limiting reactant accessibility. Chtchigrovsky et al. [80] used a similar procedure to prepare alginate-supported Pd NPs for the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction. In this case, instead of mixing the palladium salts with alginate to yield hydrogels, different metal chlorides were used as the gelling agent, and then they were partially exchanged by palladium. The procedure involved four main steps: (1) formation of alginate/Mn+ gels, (2) partial exchange of Mn+ by Pd2+, (3) reduction of Pd2+ to generate Pd NPs, and (4) drying the alcogel beads in supercritical CO2 to yield aerogel beads. In total, 36 alginate aerogels were prepared and characterized, and the metal contents of the different materials were determined by ICP analysis, the surface area and pore structure of the network were characterized by SEM analysis, while the size and dispersion of Pd NPs were detected by TEM analysis. Both the nature of Mn+ and the Pd/Mn+ ratio were shown to depend on the nature of the Pd-derived NPsMn+ [80]. The different catalysts were then employed in the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction of 4-bromoanisole with phenylboronic acid using six solvents and six bases, and both the catalytic performances and recyclability of the heterogeneous catalysts were tested. In general, the gelling metal was found to have a strong effect on the catalytic properties of the alginate aerogels in terms of both activity and recyclability. In addition, the ratio between Pd and the gelling metal strongly influenced the recyclability of the heterogeneous catalysts, and in many cases, percentages higher than 3% caused losses in catalytic efficiency. It was concluded that the copper cross-linked alginate gels were the most efficient and stable support for the palladium catalyst. Finally, performing the reactions of 15 different bromobenzenes and phenylboronic acid derivatives with alginate/Cu+2/PdNP (Cu/Pd = 97/3, 0.01 % Pd) in ethanol with K2CO3 as the base at 70 °C resulted in yields of 47–99 %. In addition, the catalyst was used for six cycles with only minor losses of activity. Budarin et al. also prepared a high surface area palladium catalyst [81] by using starch to prepare a mesoporous material via solvent exchange of the water-starch gel with ethanol and drying. This mesoporous material was dispersed together with Pd(OAc)2 in ethanol or acetone and filtered and washed with ethanol or acetone. The palladium free material was found to have a surface area of 190 m2/g with an average pore size of 8.2 nm, but the addition of palladium reduced both surface area and pore size such that Pd loading of 5 wt% blocked the pores. Employing the new heterogeneous systems in the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction of bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid under microwave heating (Table 2 ) yielded high conversions that increased with the Pd content (from 0.5 to 2.5 wt%), but a further increase did not have any effect on conversions. Neither palladium leaching nor catalyst recycling results were reported. 2.3 Cellulose nanofibers and nanocrystals as supports Cellulose, the most abundant natural organic polymer, is the main component of wooden plants. Its inter-fibril hydrogen bonds manifest a tightly packed sheet structure, yet it is very difficult to obtain nano-structured cellulose or nanocellulose [82]. Nanocellulose is produced in two main forms: as cellulose nanocrystals (CNCs) in the form of nanocrystalline cellulose (NCC) and as cellulose nanofibers (CNFs), also called cellulose nanofibrils (CNF) or nanofibrillated cellulose (NFC). These cellulose nanomaterials were recently employed not only as supports in catalysis, but also to support Pd NPs. Jebali et al. reported on the use of cellulose nanofibers as support for Pd NPs [83]. The cellulose fibers, which were extracted from Marram grass stems, were quaternized by stirring them in a suspension with dimethylacetamide, glycidyltrimethylammonium chloride and KOH. Afterward, the modified fibers were recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water and then disintegrated by a high-pressure homogenizer to yield a thick gel. In the next step, cationic cellulose nanofibrils (CCNF) were mixed with a PdCl2 solution in water, degassed and heated under vigorous stirring and N2 atmosphere. Finally, a solution of sodium borohydride in deionized water was slowly added to the mixture under stirring, and the catalyst (Pd@CCNF) was recovered by centrifugation and washing with water. The XRD diffraction pattern of Pd@CCNF indicated that Pd nanocomposites formed without any Pd(II) impurity, an observation that was confirmed by EDX and XPS analyses. A TEM analysis of Pd-supported CNF morphologies showed the presence of Pd NPs with sizes of 3−9 nm evenly distributed over the surface of the cellulose nanofibril network. Pd@CCNF was employed in the Suzuki cross-coupling of 4-bromoanisole and phenylboronic acid in research that aimed to find the optimal solvent type, base type, catalyst loading and reaction temperature [83]. The highest yield was obtained when using DMF as the solvent and K2CO3 as the base, and the reaction was run at 110 °C with catalyst loading of 0.1 mol% Pd. These conditions were therefore also employed with the six other halobenzenes, yields for which ranged from 63 % (chlorobenzene) to 99 % (4-iodoanisole). The catalyst was recycled for four successive runs, over which the yield decreased from 97 % to 68 %. Pd NPs were also formed by using the cellulose as support in the form of a sponge that was also used as a recyclable cross-coupling catalyst [84]. The cellulose-based catalyst sponge was prepared by (1) mixing dual-cross-linking cellulose nanofiber (CNF) with PdCl2 and dopamine hydrochloride, (2) the dropwise addition of γ-glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane (GPTMS) to the suspension, (3) after freezing the suspension with liquid nitrogen, the resultant frozen gel was freeze-dried and rinsed with deionized water to remove unbound materials before the final step, (4) catalyst purification by using acetone and a Soxhlet extractor to extract water that had been absorbed by the catalyst sponge. Finally, the sample was dried in a vacuum oven to yield Pd NPs@CS. The surface area of the sponge was detected by BET and found to be 10.3 m2/g. FTIR confirmed that polydopamine and CNF were chemically joined with GPTMS. XRD and XRD-EDX measurements indicated that the Pd NPs were homogeneously dispersed over the cellulose sheet, and ICP-AES analysis detected that Pd loading was 8.91 mg/g. Lastly, SEM and TEM analyses showed spherical Pd NPs that were homogeneously dispersed on the surface of the cellulose sheet with a narrow size distribution that averaged about 2.5 nm. The new catalyst was tested in 10 different reactions between iodo- and bromobenzenes together with different phenylboronic acid derivatives, and yields of 98–99 % were observed. Catalyst recycling was also tested, showing that its yield decreased from 99 % in the first cycle to 93 % in the seventh cycle. Zhang et al. synthesized Pd NPs by using dialdehyde nanocellulose as a template and reducing agent [85]. Cellulose nanofibrils (CNFs) were treated with NaIO4 to yield 2, 3-dialdehyde nanocellulose (DANC) by periodate oxidation. The DANC was suspended in water and mixed with Pd(II) complexes in liquid ammonia [Pd(NH3)4]2+. After heating the solution, the resultant PdNPs@NC precipitate was washed and separated from the suspensions by centrifugation. FTIR analyses of CNFs and DANCs confirmed that the surface of the nanocellulose had indeed been modified with aldehyde groups via periodate oxidation. In addition, the analysis for PdNPs@NC showed that the aldehyde groups disappear due to the redox reaction they undergo with the metal ions, in which the aldehyde groups were oxidized to carboxylate groups and the metal ions [Pd(II)] were reduced [Pd(0)]. TEM images showed that the average particle sizes of the Pd NPs in 0.1, 0.2 and 0.4 wt% DANCs were 19.33, 18.28 and 15.86 nm, respectively. Finally, the Suzuki cross-coupling of five different bromobenzenes and phenylboronic acid using PdNPs@NC resulted in conversions of 94–100 %. Wang et al. used cellulose nanocrystals to support Pd NPs and added guar gum to obtain a Pd NPs@CNCs/guar gum hydrogel catalyst [86]. Catalyst preparation comprised two steps. First, the Pd NPs@CNCs composite was synthesized by adding a solution of PdCl2 to a CNC suspension under stirring followed by the dropwise addition of NaBH4 to reduce the PdCl2 to Pd. Then the suspension was further dialyzed, followed by freeze-drying, after which it was used in the subsequent preparation of the Pd NPs@CNCs/guar gum hydrogel. Specifically, homogeneous aqueous solutions of guar gum and Pd NPs@CNCs composites were mixed. The dropwise addition of NaBH4, which functioned as the crosslinker, yielded the hydrogel. TEM micrographs showed that Pd NP particle sizes were in a size range of 2−6 nm, with an average of about 3 nm, while EDX and XPS analyses confirmed the presence of Pd NPs in the hydrogel and of residual Pd(II) in the catalyst. In addition, FTIR spectra showed the interactions between the hydroxyl groups of the CNCs and those of the Pd NPs. The yields of Suzuki cross-coupling in ethanol of four different bromobenzenes with two different phenylboronic acid derivatives were from 86 % to 99 %. Catalyst recycling for several cycles resulted in yields that decreased from 98 % in the first run to 90 % in the fifth run. 2.4 Comparison of Pd NP catalyst systems Various polysaccharides and their combinations have been employed as supports for the stabilization and dispersion of Pd NPs. These composites were usually prepared by mixing the native or grafted polysaccharide or its hydrogels with a palladium salt, after which the palladium was reduced using different techniques. In general, all systems required multi-step procedures and the use of extensive amounts of organic solvent for the synthesis and washing steps. The new, supported Pd NPs were used as catalysts in the Suzuki cross-coupling of various halobenzenes and different phenylboronic acid derivatives. As expected, iodo-and bromobenzenes were much more active than chlorobenzenes, and the addition of different functional groups to the aromatic ring of the halobenzene altered the reaction yield. The results, shown in Table 3 , show the varied performances of the various Pd NP systems in a representative reaction, i.e., the cross-coupling of 4-bromoanisole and phenylboronic acid. As expected, the reaction under microwave irradiation (MW) yielded higher conversions compared to running it under conventional heating (CV). Moreover, the use of MW instead of CV as the heat source allows the use of more environmentally friend solvents, like water, most of the time, or it also enables the reaction to be performed without a solvent, which is even greener. The highest TOF was detected with the alginate system, which was treated with metal chlorides to form a gel wherein the cation was then partially exchanged by palladium [80]. In addition, when Pd NPs were stabilized on highly thermally stable and biodegradable microcapsules (CAP) containing chitosan, agarose and βcyclodextrin biopolymers (Pd NPs@CAP), the TOF were also very high [76]. These highly efficient performances were attributed to the small sizes and high dispersion of the Pd NPs in those systems. Although all the catalysts could be reused, in most cases reuse entailed a loss of activity, a finding that was due mainly to the reduction in the total palladium surface area caused by the NP aggregation. 3 Summary As previously stated, we recently published a review about the recent developments in the immobilization of palladium complexes on renewable polysaccharides for the Suzuki cross-coupling of halobenzenes and phenylboronic acid derivatives [53]. A comparison of the immobilization of palladium complexes and of Pd NPs on polysaccharides shows that the preparation of immobilized complexes is usually much more labor intensive and tedious than the support of Pd NPs, yet the synthesis of Pd NPs requires the use of reducing agents. In addition, most supported Pd NP catalysts not only showed lower activity than the corresponding immobilized Pd complexes [53], they also tended to exhibit greater losses in activity during recycling due to aggregation. coredata.dc:description: In the nanotechnology era, the synthesis of nanoparticles plays a vital role in a wide range of disciplinary fields. This review summarizes the more recent advances in the synthesis of renewable polysaccharide catalysts based on palladium nanoparticles that were developed to yield heterogeneous catalysts for the Suzuki cross-coupling of halobenzenes and phenylboronic acids. In addition, the review includes an in-depth comparison of the various methods and their catalytic performance results. In general, composite synthesis was done either by mixing metal salts with a polysaccharide or by anchoring a metal complex to a polysaccharide, both procedures that involve a subsequent reduction of the metal. The heterogeneous systems were tested in the Suzuki cross-coupling of halobenzenes and phenylboronic acids under conventional heating or microwave irradiation. All the systems showed high activity, and the catalysts could be easily recycled and reused.
coredata.dc:title: Development and application of palladium nanoparticles on renewable polysaccharides as catalysts for the Suzuki cross-coupling of halobenzenes and phenylboronic acids
